Similarly, when both inputs are at logic level 0, the output remains at logic level 0 since there is no true input to perform the OR operation on.

name: DIAC-characteristics-curve.PNG
explanation:
The image is a diagram that shows the characteristics of a DIAC (Differential Inductor for AC) circuit. The DIAC is composed of two main parts: the first part, labeled as "2nd Quadrant," consists of a reverse breakdown voltage and a reverse current curve. The second part, labeled as "1st Quadrant," includes an old state curve and a forward voltage drop curve. Both quadrants are connected by a C-E terminal and an M-O terminal.

In the 2nd Quadrant, the reverse breakdown voltage curve represents the maximum voltage at which the DIAC can be operated in reverse mode. This curve indicates that the DIAC will conduct when the voltage across it reaches this value. The reverse current curve shows the amount of current flowing through the DIAC at different voltages. As the voltage increases, the current also increases until it reaches the maximum value allowed by the DIAC's design.

In the 1st Quadrant, the old state curve represents the operating point of the DIAC when it is conducting in the forward direction. The forward voltage drop curve shows the voltage drop across the DIAC as the current increases. At this point, the DIAC acts as a voltage-controlled switch, allowing current to flow only when the voltage across it reaches a certain threshold.

The DIAC is connected to a C-E terminal and an M-O terminal. These terminals allow the DIAC to be integrated into larger circuits, such as power supplies or rectifiers.

The following characteristic curve shows the relation between the main voltage and main current of a DIAC. As you can see, the DIAC only operate in 1st and 3rd quadrant. It is a symmetrical device; therefore, the graph is symmetrical in both quadrants forming the shape of letter ‚ÄúZ‚Äù.In 1st quadrant, the voltage and current are positive. As you can see, when the voltage is below the break over voltage VBO, the DIAC blocks the current except for the leakage current. The device remains in OFF-state. The device operates similarly in the 3rd quadrant. The only difference between the 1st and 3rd quadrant is that the voltage and current are reverse. That is it.

Break Over Voltage (VB): By increasing the anode-cathode voltage beyond a specific threshold called the breakover voltage (VB), the reverse-biased junction J2 breaks down. This results in a large current flow through the SCR.
Gate Triggering: By applying a positive voltage to the gate terminal (G) relative to the cathode (K), the SCR can be triggered into conduction without requiring the voltage to reach the breakover level. The gate current induces carriers in the J2 junction, making it conductive and allowing current to flow from anode to cathode.

name: SCR-as-Full-Wave-Rectifier.jpg
explanation: The image is a diagram of a full-wave rectifier circuit using two SCR (Silicon Controlled Rectifier) devices. The circuit is designed to convert an alternating current (AC) input into a direct current (DC) output, which can be used in various electronic applications such as power supplies and motor control circuits. In the circuit diagram, there are two SCR devices connected in parallel with their gate terminals connected to the negative terminal of the AC source. The cathode terminals of both SCRs are connected together and then connected to the positive terminal of the AC source. The anode terminals of the SCRs are connected to the load, which in this case is represented by a resistor and a capacitor. When the AC voltage increases from zero, it triggers the first SCR to conduct, allowing current to flow through the load. As the AC voltage decreases, the second SCR begins to trigger, creating a continuous path for current to flow through the load. This process continues until the AC voltage returns to zero, at which point both SCRs are no longer conducting, effectively cutting off the DC output. The waveform shown below the circuit diagram represents the output of the full-wave rectifier circuit. It shows the voltage across the load over time, with the peaks representing the maximum voltage achieved during each half-cycle of the AC input.
corrected_explanation: For full-wave rectification two SCRs are connected across the centre taped secondary, as shown in figure-a. The gates of both SCRs are supplied from two gate control supply circuits. One SCR conducts during the positive half cycle and the other during the negative half cycle and thus unidirectional current flows in the load circuit. The main advantage of this circuit over ordinary full-wave rectifier circuit is that the output voltage can be controlled by adjusting the gate current.

where Vf is the forward voltage drop of the diode and Ir is the current flowing through the circuit.
